title: Semi-automating the Reading Programme for a Historical Dictionary Project
segmentation: I am going to talk about a very practical exercise so.
Rather, a tiny project which we have been doing over the last.

1 1/2 years together with the lexicography you will need for South African English at Rhodes University in South Africa, and most of the work has actually been done by Tymphany Kirk, who is the technical editor of the dictionary, as well as by Johannes Schaefer and hikers toddler my collaborators in Hildesheim.
I will briefly talk about the Dictionary of South African English, characterize it, show how it has evolved over the last.
3540 years and it tell you what we are currently investigating in our experimental setup.
And then come to to worlds for dictionary updating or for the automation of the reading program after dictionary.

So what is the Dictionary of South African English?

Historical principles it is an variety Dictionary of English, a weedy style and diachronic in The Sims that, given the history of South Africa, you can rather exactly talk about the beginning if you like, or the first manifestations of the South African variety of the language, and then follow it.
Development over the years.
A as a particular a specificity.
This dictionary contains a large amount of quotations and is the major source of information on South African English and also on certain things, phenomena.
Objects which are typical of the South African society.
The dictionary's history.
Anne is such that it was prepared from the 1970s onwards to be published in 1996 in a print version, Whoops.

In a print version covering the period up to a 1990 roughly, and that version was sold out already in 2004, so the paper version, voice and available and the people at the dictionary unit started to think about an online version, which then is saw the light.
In 2014, and is still available online at the URL you have on the right side of the transparency.
Currently the Dictionaries Society is planning a revision of the dictionary and.
Our joint project Voice in experimental action, which aimed at checking the possibilities of using online corpus data to document current South African usage.
So basically the period comprised between 2011 and 2017.
The principles underlying the dictionary, as far as the macro structure is concerned, I already said that it is an OG style dictionary.
It has roughly four and a half thousand lemmas plus 6000 orthographic.
Variants of these lemmas and another 4000 derivatives and components and it provides.
A typical data categories you would expect, so lemme assign orthographic variants.

Inflection forms which due to the fact that many of the items come either from Africans or from the African languages, sometimes tend not to fit the standard English paradigms, grammatical and pronunciation information, etymology and word history.
So it does exactly what Patrick hangs.
Eluded to, it shows a the varied history, so to say it has DIA systematic Marks and meaning paraphrases.
And synonym indications and above all, as I said, it has 45,000 quotations which are fully bibliographically documented and have been derived from a manual reading program.
And this is exactly.
Where the objectives of the current little experiment come into play.
The question was how to speed up the reading program process, which is, you know when carried out manually consists in identifying items to be dealt with.
Identifying quotations, correcting these quotations, putting them into some database for later use, and finally.

Selecting from them for dictionary publication, but we know did was to create a corpus covering a last few years 2011, two 2017 as a source for extracting raw material, and the idea was to find new quotations for lemmas which are already in the dictionary.

To cover all known orthographic variants to possibly find new orthographic variants to also establish what the current use of the different orthographic variances in quantitative terms, and finally to go is step towards finding ulima candidates and quotations again to document them.
So we basically compiled ourselves a smaller.
Your News Corp was covering the years to 2015 to 17 with a collection of online newspapers from South Africa.
You've got the list on the transparency and we collected this data on a daily basis trying to document them as much as possible with meta data.
This gave roundabout 100 million verts of.
A well documented newspaper text.
The second source was provided by the colleagues at Leipzig University from their project called Curl Crawling under Resourced Languages.
What they had been doing over quite a while was to collect Internet data from this South African domain, it to collect them in a sentence wise scrambled collection.
But unfortunately this.
Corpus it doesn't contain as many meta data as we would have liked the test, just rather limited amount.
On the contrary, in quantitative terms it is quite important with its 3 billion vert.

So for 85% of these.

A 7000 we found we found a sufficient amount of quotations and for around 50% of the candidates we had around 100 quotation candidates, which is quite a bit for a lexicographer to select appropriate ones from.

As far as variant search goes, we first of all expanded the information from the existing dictionary in such a way as to be able to know about all the variants which we could already cover, and then we compared with what we found.
In the corpus an.
This is interesting, especially when it comes to words which come from languages like the African languages where sometimes writers use different orthographic form.
So this impe poor also comes as a paper as a paper as paper and so on and so forth.
And we note the number of forms found in the dictionary.
As well as how distant they are from the original dictionary.
Entry.
Ann for longer words.
A more relaxed comparison was used, and so if you have an example like Carrie key people.
Also, Carrie Kimmins was found which just uses the Afrikaans word Mensa instead of its English equivalent people.
And you see that the English writers use it sometimes with a- and sometimes interesting Lee even with a plural S as in the bottom example, Carrick easements.
So you find a whole series of.
A variant in current writing.

The search for inclusion candidates to some extent is a side effect of variant search in the way that, for example, we started with bradia traditional African wedding gift and we also found by change of two of the consonants muladi, which is a system for constructing walls in expensive houses.
And that was an item which hadn't been contained so far in the dictionary.
In the very bottom line of the examples, you also see that this was quantitatively prominent, so the lexicographers can also help themselves by using at the.
Observed frequency after date.

Another way of searching for inclusion candidates as I said, is this kind of standard term extraction based procedure and on this slide you've got again a number of examples which have been found by this device.
What we have shown, I think, is.

That with rather standard and simplistic methods, a corpus compiled from online news and from Internet data could be used for documenting the work on the Dictionary of South African English, and we used that for spelling variants and inclusion candidates.

Basically, using very common standard technology, but obviously all of that material still needs to be further checked by lexicographic experts, and that is what is currently going on in Grahamstown, South Africa, but they tell us that getting this material already in this kind of pre structured form is quite useful and speeds up there.

This is what we intend to do in the future is to further explore this data qualitatively and quantitatively to have more devices for reducing the amount of data we make available to the lexicographers and to make the tool based workflow directly available to the lexicographers in such a way that when your data there are crawled or made available in some fashion, they can run the procedures themselves.
Thank you very much for your attention.
So in terms of relative frequency, could you talk just a little bit more about how you filter out noise when you are trying to identify new candidates for inclusion?
Yeah, thank you Ann so.
The simplest thing which can be done is obviously a in line with standard terminology extraction procedures where you use a number of statistical form.
You lay a basically either for corpus comparison.
A in the sense of comparison of relative frequency or for multi verts, standard collocation measures.
And then we start obviously from the top ranked ones.
Basically what we do here.
Is not just use standard comparison of a relative frequencies as it was introduced by Ahmad in the 90s but run a few further statistics on the thing and so basically start working on the top ones.
However, the lexicographers tell us that some of the less prominently ranked items are equally.
A of interest as inclusion candidates and there.
Actually I must admit that at the current stage they have to work through quite an amount of noise, so that is something we still have to work on to get more focused results.
